message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: A Survey of Path Planning Algorithms for Mobile Robots
Paper Abstract: Path planning algorithms are used by mobile robots, unmanned aerial vehicles, and autonomous cars in order to identify safe, efficient, collision-free, and least-cost travel paths from an origin to a destination. Choosing an appropriate path planning algorithm helps to ensure safe and effective point-to-point navigation, and the optimal algorithm depends on the robot geometry as well as the computing constraints, including static/holonomic and dynamic/non-holonomically-constrained systems, and requires a comprehensive understanding of contemporary solutions. The goal of this paper is to help novice practitioners gain an awareness of the classes of path planning algorithms used today and to understand their potential use cases—particularly within automated or unmanned systems. To that end, we provide broad, rather than deep, coverage of key and foundational algorithms, with popular algorithms and variants considered in the context of different robotic systems. The definitions, summaries, and comparisons are relevant to novice robotics engineers and embedded system developers seeking a primer of available algorithms.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

I found comprehensive information about mobile robots. Here's an overview:

## Definition and Basics

A mobile robot is an automatic machine that is capable of locomotion.(no content)Mobile robots have the capability to move around in their environment and are not fixed to one physical location.(no content)Mobile robotics is usually considered to be a subfield of robotics and information engineering.

## Components

The components of a mobile robot are a controller, sensors, actuators and power system.(no content)The controller is generally a microprocessor, embedded microcontroller or a personal computer (PC).

## Applications

Mobile robots are used across various sectors:
- Hospitals have been using autonomous mobile robots to move materials for many years.
- Warehouses have installed mobile robotic systems to efficiently move materials from stocking shelves to order fulfillment zones.
- Mobile robots are also found in industrial, military and security settings.

## Research

Mobile robots are also a major focus of current research and almost every major university has one or more labs that focus on mobile robot research.

The search results also contain information about specific mobile robot models (like Khepera, e-puck, and Shakey), industrial applications, and research software frameworks used in mobile robotics development.

Web search results for query: "Holonomic constraint"

Links: [{"title":"Holonomic constraints - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holonomic_constraints"},{"title":"Constraint (mechanics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constraint_(mechanics)"},{"title":"Nonholonomic system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonholonomic_system"},{"title":"Generalized coordinates - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Generalized_coordinates"},{"title":"Holonomic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holonomic"},{"title":"Talk:Camber thrust - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Camber_thrust"},{"title":"Pfaffian constraint - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pfaffian_constraint"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about holonomic constraints:

## Definition

In classical mechanics, holonomic constraints are relations between the position variables (and possibly time). More specifically, holonomic constraints are expressible as a function of the coordinates and time.

## Key Characteristics

A system is a holonomic system if and only if all its constraints are Pfaffian and integrable.(no content)If the differential form is integrable, i.e., if there is a function, then this constraint is a holonomic constraint; otherwise, it is nonholonomic.

## Examples

Examples of holonomic systems are gantry cranes, pendulums, and robotic arms. In contrast, examples of nonholonomic systems are Segways, unicycles, and automobiles.

A practical example: the motion of a particle constrained to lie on the surface of a sphere is subject to a holonomic constraint, but if the particle is able to fall off the sphere under the influence of gravity, the constraint becomes non-holonomic.

## Significance in Mechanics

For a system with holonomic constraints, its dynamics is restricted to a submanifold of the full configuration space. Therefore, we can make a coordinate chart only on an individual submanifold, which then allows us to eliminate the constraints, since any trajectory within an individual submanifold automatically satisfy all constraints. The coordinate chart on that is called generalized coordinates and is the foundation of Lagrangian mechanics.

Web search results for query: "Collision detection"

Links: [{"title":"Carrier-sense multiple access with collision detection - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carrier-sense_multiple_access_with_collision_detection"},{"title":"Collision detection - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collision_detection"},{"title":"Collision avoidance (networking) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collision_avoidance_(networking)"},{"title":"Collision (telecommunications) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collision_(telecommunications)"},{"title":"Collision avoidance system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collision_avoidance_system"},{"title":"Traffic collision avoidance system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Traffic_collision_avoidance_system"},{"title":"Maritime Collision Avoidance System - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maritime_Collision_Avoidance_System"},{"title":"Bounding volume - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bounding_volume"},{"title":"Automated emergency braking system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automated_emergency_braking_system"},{"title":"Hyperplane separation theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyperplane_separation_theorem"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about collision detection:

## Overview

Collision detection is the computational problem of detecting an intersection of two or more objects in virtual space, dealing with the questions of if, when and where two or more objects intersect.(no content)Collision detection is a classic problem of computational geometry with applications in computer graphics, physical simulation, video games, robotics (including autonomous driving) and computational physics.

## How It Works

Collision detection is closely linked to calculating the distance between objects, as objects collide when the distance between them is less than or equal to zero.(no content)Performing collision detection requires more context than just the distance between the objects; accurately identifying the points of contact on both objects' surfaces is also essential for the computation of a physically accurate collision response.

## Two-Phase Approach

A commonly used approach towards accelerating the required computations is to divide the process into two phases: the broad phase and the narrow phase. The broad phase aims to answer the question of whether objects might collide, using a conservative but efficient approach to rule out pairs that clearly do not intersect.(no content)Objects that cannot be definitively separated in the broad phase are passed to the narrow phase. Here, more precise algorithms determine whether these objects actually intersect. If they do, the narrow phase often calculates the exact time and location of the intersection.

## Practical Applications

It is essential for interactive applications like video games, robotics, and real-time physics engines.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Unmanned aerial vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicle"},{"title":"List of unmanned aerial vehicles - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_unmanned_aerial_vehicles"},{"title":"History of unmanned aerial vehicles - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_unmanned_aerial_vehicles"},{"title":"Unmanned combat aerial vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_combat_aerial_vehicle"},{"title":"Unmanned aerial vehicles in the United States military - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicles_in_the_United_States_military"},{"title":"412th Unmanned Aerial Vehicle Regiment (Ukraine) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/412th_Unmanned_Aerial_Vehicle_Regiment_(Ukraine)"},{"title":"List of unmanned aerial vehicle applications - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_unmanned_aerial_vehicle_applications"},{"title":"Uncrewed vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_vehicle"},{"title":"Category:Unmanned aerial vehicle manufacturers of the United States - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Unmanned_aerial_vehicle_manufacturers_of_the_United_States"},{"title":"List of unmanned aerial vehicle-related incidents - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_unmanned_aerial_vehicle-related_incidents"}]

I've completed the web search for "Unmanned aerial vehicle." Here's what I found:

## Overview

An unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) or unmanned aircraft system (UAS), commonly known as a drone, is an aircraft with no human pilot, crew, or passengers on board, but rather is controlled remotely or is autonomous.

## Technical Definition

A UAV is capable of controlled, sustained level flight and is powered by a jet, reciprocating, or electric engine.

## Applications

Unmanned aerial vehicles are used across the world for civilian, commercial, as well as military applications. Examples include aerial photography, crop surveying, search and rescue, power line inspection, wildlife counting, and delivery of medical supplies.

## History

The earliest recorded use of an unmanned aerial vehicle for warfighting occurred in July 1849, with Austrian forces besieging Venice attempting to launch some 200 incendiary balloons at the besieged city.(no content)In 2006, the United States Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) allowed the usage of unmanned aerial vehicles inside civilian airspace with specific regulations.

## Consumer Market

In 2013, DJI released the first model of the Phantom drone at $629, which was considered one of the most influential consumer drone products ever made.(no content)By 2017, DJI alone had over 75% of the global consumer drone market share.

Web search results for query: "Autonomous vehicle"

Links: [{"title":"Cruise (autonomous vehicle) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cruise_(autonomous_vehicle)"},{"title":"Autonomous underwater vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_underwater_vehicle"},{"title":"Self-driving car - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-driving_car"},{"title":"List of predictions for autonomous Tesla vehicles by Elon Musk - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_predictions_for_autonomous_Tesla_vehicles_by_Elon_Musk"},{"title":"Vehicular automation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vehicular_automation"},{"title":"Autonomous aircraft - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_aircraft"},{"title":"Autonomous racing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_racing"},{"title":"Waymo - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Waymo"},{"title":"Wayve - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wayve"},{"title":"Unmanned aerial vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicle"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of autonomous vehicles:

## Definition

A self-driving car, also known as an autonomous car (AC), driverless car, robotic car or robo-car, is a car that is capable of operating with reduced or no human input.

## Levels of Autonomy

The Society of Automotive Engineers (SAE) classifies road vehicle autonomy in six levels: Level 1 is driver assistance where the vehicle controls steering or speed autonomously in specific circumstances; Level 2 is partial automation where the vehicle controls both steering and speed autonomously in specific circumstances; Level 3 is conditional automation where the vehicle controls both steering and speed under normal environmental conditions but requires the driver to be ready to take control in other circumstances; Level 4 is high automation where the vehicle travels autonomously under normal environmental conditions, not requiring driver oversight; and Level 5 is full autonomy where the vehicle can complete travel autonomously in any environmental conditions.

## Key Technologies

Autonomous vehicle software generally contains several different modules that work together to enable self-driving capabilities. The perception module ingests and processes data from various sensors, such cameras, LIDAR, RADAR, and ultrasonic SONAR, to create a comprehensive understanding of the vehicle's surroundings. The localization module uses 3D point cloud data, GPS, IMU, and mapping information to determine the vehicle's precise position. The planning module takes inputs from both perception and localization to compute actions to take, such as velocity and steering angle outputs.

## Current Commercial Services

Waymo operates commercial robotaxi services available to the public in Phoenix, the San Francisco Bay Area, Los Angeles, Atlanta, and Austin, and as of December 2025, it operates over 450,000 rides per week.

Web search results for query: "Robot navigation"

Links: [{"title":"Robot navigation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot_navigation"},{"title":"Category:Robot navigation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Robot_navigation"},{"title":"Robotic mapping - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robotic_mapping"},{"title":"Mobile robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mobile_robot"},{"title":"Automated guided vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automated_guided_vehicle"},{"title":"Simultaneous localization and mapping - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simultaneous_localization_and_mapping"},{"title":"Evolution Robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolution_Robotics"},{"title":"Distributed architecture for mobile navigation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_architecture_for_mobile_navigation"},{"title":"Layered costmaps - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Layered_costmaps"},{"title":"AVM Navigator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AVM_Navigator"}]

Based on the web search results, here's a comprehensive overview of robot navigation:

## What is Robot Navigation?

Robot navigation means the robot's ability to determine its own position in its frame of reference and then to plan a path towards some goal location.(no content)In order to navigate in its environment, the robot or any other mobility device requires representation—a map of the environment and the ability to interpret that representation.

## Key Types of Navigation Systems

**Autonomous Mobile Robots (AMRs):** Autonomous mobile robots are capable of navigating an uncontrolled environment without the need for physical or electro-mechanical guidance devices.

**Automated Guided Vehicles (AGVs):** An automated guided vehicle is a portable robot that follows along marked long lines or wires on the floor, or uses radio waves, vision cameras, magnets, or lasers for navigation.

## Navigation Technologies

**Vision-Based Navigation:** Vision-based navigation uses computer vision algorithms and optical sensors, including laser-based range finder and photometric cameras using CCD arrays, to extract the visual features required to localization in the surrounding environment.

**SLAM (Simultaneous Localization and Mapping):** Simultaneous localization and mapping is the computational problem of constructing or updating a map of an unknown environment while simultaneously keeping track of an agent's location within it.

**Additional Positioning Methods:** Autonomous underwater vehicles can be guided by underwater acoustic positioning systems, sonar navigation systems have also been developed, and robots can determine their positions using radio navigation.

## Applications

Hospitals have been using autonomous mobile robots to move materials for many years, and warehouses have installed mobile robotic systems to efficiently move materials from stocking shelves to order fulfillment zones.

Based on the web search results, here's a comprehensive overview of robot navigation:

## What is Robot Navigation?

Robot navigation means the robot's ability to determine its own position in its frame of reference and then to plan a path towards some goal location.(no content)In order to navigate in its environment, the robot or any other mobility device requires representation—a map of the environment and the ability to interpret that representation.

## Key Types of Navigation Systems

**Autonomous Mobile Robots (AMRs):** Autonomous mobile robots are capable of navigating an uncontrolled environment without the need for physical or electro-mechanical guidance devices.

**Automated Guided Vehicles (AGVs):** An automated guided vehicle is a portable robot that follows along marked long lines or wires on the floor, or uses radio waves, vision cameras, magnets, or lasers for navigation.

## Navigation Technologies

**Vision-Based Navigation:** Vision-based navigation uses computer vision algorithms and optical sensors, including laser-based range finder and photometric cameras using CCD arrays, to extract the visual features required to localization in the surrounding environment.

**SLAM (Simultaneous Localization and Mapping):** Simultaneous localization and mapping is the computational problem of constructing or updating a map of an unknown environment while simultaneously keeping track of an agent's location within it.

**Additional Positioning Methods:** Autonomous underwater vehicles can be guided by underwater acoustic positioning systems, sonar navigation systems have also been developed, and robots can determine their positions using radio navigation.

## Applications

Hospitals have been using autonomous mobile robots to move materials for many years, and warehouses have installed mobile robotic systems to efficiently move materials from stocking shelves to order fulfillment zones.

Here are the web search results for "Path planning":

## Overview

Path planning (also known as motion planning, the navigation problem, or the piano mover's problem) is a computational problem to find a sequence of valid configurations that moves the object from the source to destination.(no content)The term is used in computational geometry, computer animation, robotics and computer games.

## Key Approaches

There are several main categories of path planning algorithms:

1. **Any-Angle Path Planning**: Any-angle path planning algorithms are pathfinding algorithms that search for a Euclidean shortest path between two points on a grid map while allowing the turns in the path to have any angle.

2. **Sampling-Based Algorithms**: Sampling-based algorithms represent the configuration space with a roadmap of sampled configurations. A basic algorithm samples N configurations in C, and retains those in Cfree to use as milestones. A roadmap is then constructed that connects two milestones P and Q if the line segment PQ is completely in Cfree.

3. **Real-Time Path Planning**: Real-Time Path Planning consists of motion planning methods that can adapt to real time changes in the environment, including everything from primitive algorithms that stop a robot when it approaches an obstacle to more complex algorithms that continuously takes in information from the surroundings and creates a plan to avoid obstacles.

## Applications

Any-angle path planning are useful for robot navigation and real-time strategy games where more optimal paths are desirable. Additionally, as a subset of motion planning, it is an important part of robotics as it allows robots to find the optimal path to a target. This ability to find an optimal path also plays an important role in other fields such as video games and gene sequencing.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of non-holonomic systems:

## Definition

A nonholonomic system in classical mechanics is a physical system with some constraints that are impossible to be cast into the form of holonomic constraints. More intuitively, they are mechanical systems with constraints on their velocity that are not derivable from position constraints.

## Key Characteristics

They are contrasted with classical Lagrangian and Hamiltonian systems, in which there are only constraints on position. The distinction can be understood mathematically: A system is a nonholonomic system, if and only if all its constraints are Pfaffian, but some are not integrable.

## Practical Examples

A classic example is an upright wheel on a plane (sometimes visualized as a unicycle or a rolling upright coin) which is a nonholonomic system with a single Pfaffian constraint. Another intuitive example is the rolling of a ball on a table, because one rolling along different paths to the same point can put it into different orientations.

## Applications

In robotics, nonholonomic has been studied in the scope of motion planning and feedback linearization for mobile robots. A practical application is that non-holonomic solutions can be arbitrarily well approximated by holonomic ones (by going back and forth, like parallel parking in a limited space), which implies that it is possible to parallel park in any space longer than the length of your car.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
Excellent! All tasks completed successfully. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Complete ✅

**Paper Classification:** Survey

**Extracted Triples (8 total):**

1. **Motion planning** (method) - Path planning algorithms are fundamental motion planning methods used to guide robots to destinations safely and efficiently.

2. **Mobile robot** (task) - Mobile robots are a primary application domain for path planning algorithms in autonomous navigation.

3. **Unmanned aerial vehicle** (task) - Unmanned aerial vehicles require path planning algorithms to autonomously navigate and complete missions.

4. **Self-driving car** (task) - Autonomous cars depend on path planning algorithms to determine collision-free routes in dynamic traffic environments.

5. **Collision detection** (method) - Collision detection is essential for ensuring path planning algorithms generate collision-free trajectories.

6. **Holonomic constraints** (concept) - Holonomic constraints describe motion limitations in robot kinematics that path planning algorithms must accommodate.

7. **Nonholonomic system** (concept) - Non-holonomic constraints impose velocity-based limitations on mobile robots that path planning algorithms must handle.

8. **Robot navigation** (task) - Robot navigation is the overarching task that path planning algorithms enable by determining safe point-to-point routes.

**Validation Status:** ✅ PASSED
- All Wikipedia URLs verified
- All validation checks passed
- Entity types correctly assigned: 2 methods, 4 tasks, 2 concepts

The triples_output.json file has been successfully updated with all the key technologies and methodologies referenced in this path planning survey.
